repnme.cdata!:
Croatia - Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan, Enterprise and Financial Sector Technical
            Assistance, and Capital Markets Development Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise And Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan Project (EFSAL) is rated moderately
            unsatisfactory; its sustainability is likely; institutional
            development impact is modest; and Bank and Borrower
            performance both unsatisfactory. The project outcome of the
            Enterprise And Financial Sector Technical Assistance Project
            (TAL) is moderately satisfactory; sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is modest; Bank performance
            is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is unsatisfactory.
            For the Capital Markets Development Project (CMDP), outcome
            is rated moderately unsatisfactory; sustainability is
            unlikely; institutional development impact is modest; and
            both Bank and Borrower performance are unsatisfactory.
            Lessons of general applicability include the following: 1)
            Without complementary measures for facilitating entry and
            exit, maintaining hard budgetary constraints, and imposing
            corporate managerial accountability, privatization is
            unlikely to produce significant growth or productivity
            benefits. 2) Troubled banks should be liquidated or
            privatized quickly, and their lending strictly controlled
            while in that process. 3) The experience with the EFSAL
            suggests that, although additional delays may be incurred
            and costs increased, on balance long-run development
            benefits are likely to be enhanced by canceling projects
            with major design flaws and addressing the reform needs with
            a superior instrument. 4) Development of domestic capital
            markets makes little sense, until basic issues for private
            sector development, such as privatization and financial
            stabilization, have been resolved.

abstracts.cdata!:
Achievement of the project objectives is
            judged to be satisfactory. This project was designed as an
            ancillary project, intended to facilitate implementation of
            the Enterprise and Financial Sector Adjustment Loan (EFSAL),
            and therefore should be viewed in that context. To some
            extent, delays in implementing policy reforms of the EFSAL,
            particularly in the energy sector, have diminished the
            impact of some of the preparatory activities financed under
            the TAL. Project sustainability, where applicable, is
            considered likely: policy dialogue continues and it appears
            that the new Government is committed to continuing reforms
            in order for Croatia to become a full-fledged market
            economy. World Bank performance in all aspects of the
            project cycle was satisfactory while the performance of the
            Borrower's implementing agencies was, overall,
            satisfactory. Lessons learned include the following: The
            flexibility in TAL's design allowed project
            implementation to continue both when technical assistance
            priorities changed and when alternative financing was found.
            The project management structure was adapted specifically to
            support the government's large reform program. The fact
            that several implementing agencies were each given
            responsibility for executing their own components avoided
            creation of a bottleneck which would have appeared had all
            procurement gone through the Project Implementation Unit
            that was managing a second Bank-financed project at the same time.

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall aim of the Technical
            Assistance Project is to support the government's
            enterprise and financial sector reform program which will be
            supported by the Enterprise and Financial Sector Adjustment
            Loan currently under preparation. Specifically, the
            objectives of the project are: 1) to assist the government
            to complete the privatization of former socially-owned
            enterprises (FSOEs); 2) to help in the restructuring and
            privatization of public enterprises (PEs) through studies
            and advisory services; and 3) to support the rehabilitation
            and privatization of the banking system. The components of
            the project are the following: 1) privatization of FSOEs,
            including the recruitment of consultants/privatization
            advisors; 2) restructuring and privatization of PEs, which
            will consist of: (a) the hiring a financial analyst and an
            audit expert to assist the Office for the Restructuring and
            Economics of State-owned Enterprises (ORESE); (b) a Kutina
            Fertilizer Company, strategic planning and restructuring
            study; (b) an Industrija Nafte (petrochemical company)
            study; (c) complementary studies in the power sector; (d) a
            tariff study for the Croatian Post and Telecommunications;
            and (e) a spectrum management study; and 3) rehabilitation
            and privatization of the banking system comprising: (a) a
            legal advisor for the Bank Rehabilitation Agency (BRA); (b)
            accounting and miscellaneous services for the BRA; (c) a
            senior advisor for rehabilitation; and (d) financial
            advisory services.
